entry.title: My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - What's new?
entry.content:
The 2508 release of My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition introduces a range of new delivered and beta features, along with UX enhancements designed to elevate your overall experience. In this blog, I‚Äôll walk you through these updates and what they mean for you. 

My Home offers immediate access to key business insights, supports efficient management of tasks and situations, and allows you to organize your favorite pages and apps to streamline daily operations. The 2508 release builds on this foundation by further enhancing each of these areas. 

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Release My Home

 

One of the standout additions is the new personalized salutation bar, which greets every business user upon entering My Home. This feature not only creates a more personalized experience but also helps users quickly orient themselves within SAP S/4HANA. Now enable communication scenario SAP_COM_0887 and let business users see what‚Äôs next on their calendar at a glance. Additionally, the salutation bar consolidates all of My Home‚Äôs global actions in one convenient place‚Äîit enables users to easily add content, quickly access My Home settings, and discover the latest feature introduced in the 2508 release: Recap. 

My Home 2508 Salutation bar

 

The Recap feature introduced in the My Home 2508 release is designed to save time by helping business users stay on top of key items that have emerged since their last login. It highlights high-priority information, enabling users to quickly focus on what matters most. By surfacing relevant updates and simplifying daily tasks, Recap reduces manual effort and helps users catch up efficiently‚Äîso they can shift their attention to higher-value activities. 

My Home 2508 Recap of Tasks

 

 My Home 2508 Recap of Insights

 

Recap analyzes changes in My Home data over the past 24 hours, keeping business users informed about new tasks, situations, and updates to app, tile, and insights card access. It also provides visual comparisons of insights cards, making it easy to quickly and intuitively understand what has changed during your absence. 

The Salutation Bar also allows business users to easily add content to My Home from a centralized location. But that‚Äôs just the beginning‚Äîit now supports AI-assisted content addition, enabling users to add Insights cards using natural language. Users can also preview Insights cards during the addition process to ensure data accuracy and consistency. 

My Home 2508 AI-assisted Smart Personalization Insights Card Addition

With the 2508 release, business users can take advantage of a new Beta AI-assisted Smart Personalization App Addition feature that enables the addition of applications using natural language. This significantly streamlines the process of adding applications, saving time and offering a more intuitive, click-efficient experience‚Äî which is particularly valuable for first-time or occasional users. The feature also enhances transparency by displaying application descriptions and real-time KPIs for dynamic tiles, providing immediate operational context. 

My Home 2508 Beta AI-assisted Smart Personalization App Addition

My Home serves as the central hub for all your tasks, applications, and information. In the 2508 release, improvements have been made with the Recap and AI-assisted content addition features. Additionally, administrators are now empowered to deliver timely, targeted updates directly to business users via the My Home centralized news feed. 

With the addition of the Mange News application, administrators can create news articles to be displayed on My Home. They can categorize, target and manage the visibility of the news. Tailoring communication to your organization needs helps create a more informed and connected workforce. This in turn enhances business users‚Äôs performance by equipping them with the information needed to make smarter, faster decisions. 

My Home Manage News Application

 

 

My Home 2508 News Article Creation

 

My Home 2508 Critical News Article

We hope everyone enjoys the new features of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release ‚Äì stay tuned for more updates! The Beta AI-assisted Smart Personalization App Addition in My Home, highlighted in this article, are now available for Beta Testing with the 2508 release. At SAP, we‚Äôre committed to delivering the best experience possible, which is why we‚Äôre inviting you to join our Beta Testing Program. By participating, you‚Äôll get early access to these features, have the chance to share your feedback, and help us fine-tune them before the official launch. Your input will play a key role in shaping the quality and usability of these new capabilities. 

Also, If you are interested in hearing about the latest innovations in SAP Cloud ERP, please join our Public Cloud Practitioner Forum in which SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition customers share best practices and provide feedback to the SAP development teams about new functionality. 

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/public-cloud-means-continuous-innovation-and-continuous-learning-new-user/ba-p/14017362 

(Open to SAP Cloud ERP customers, including partners running SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition.) 

Suneet Agarwal and Caroline Welsh 

Cloud ERP UX Foundations Product Management

entry.title: Re: to update or add configuration material characteristi...
entry.content:
If CUOBJ is missing, you must trigger the creation of the configuration instance before updating characteristics. Options are to use transaction IE02 manually to open and save the equipment; this often triggers CUOBJ creation. Simulate this behavior via BAPI_EQUI_CHANGE or BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE if classification is used. Please note CUOBJ is not created unless the equipment is classified or linked to a configuration profile.

If your KMAT characteristics are maintained via classification, you can bypass CUOBJ and use:

  • BAPI_OBJCL_CHANGE
  • BAPI_OBJCL_CREATE
  • BAPI_OBJCL_GETDETAIL

These work with:

  • OBJECTKEY = EQUI-EQUNR
  • OBJECTTABLE = EQUI
  • CLASSTYPE = 002 (for equipment)

This method updates characteristics via class assignment, not variant configuration.

If you prefer a batch approach, use FM CLMM_MAINTAIN_CLASSIFICATIONS, Or use LSMW with object 0130 and method 0002 (Direct Input). This allows mass updates without needing CUOBJ.

entry.title: Re: Parameter id ‚ÄúUKM_SEGMENT‚Äù value doesn‚Äôt automaticall...
entry.content:
To default the Credit Segment field in transaction UKM_CASE, setting the parameter ID UKM_SEGMENT alone is not sufficient. This parameter helps prefill the value in some contexts, but UKM_CASE relies heavily on case attributes and configuration profiles. Here's how you can ensure the Credit Segment is defaulted properly:

SAP Credit Management uses attribute profiles to define default values for cases. Go to SPRO ‚Üí Financial Supply Chain Management ‚Üí Credit Management ‚Üí Credit Risk Monitoring ‚Üí Documented Credit Decision ‚Üí Define Attribute Profile. Find the profile used for your credit cases (e.g., UKM_CREDIT_CASE). In the attribute group, ensure that Credit Segment is included and marked as defaultable.

If the default still doesn‚Äôt populate, implement the BADI UKM_DCD_MAINTAIN where you can programmatically set the default Credit Segment based on user ID, business partner, or other logic.

Ensure the parameter ID UKM_SEGMENT is set correctly in your user profile. Go to SU3 or SU01, add parameter ID UKM_SEGMENT, Value: ES20. This works only if the field in UKM_CASE is linked to the parameter ID ‚Äî not all fields are.

entry.title: Re: Recording Additional Costs on a Purchase Order in SAP...
entry.content:
If the freight/customs costs are known at the time of PO creation, use the ‚ÄúCreate Purchase Order ‚Äì Advanced‚Äù app, add a freight condition type (e.g., FRA1, FVA1) in the PO item or header, assign the freight supplier (Supplier B) in the condition details. This allows you to create two separate invoices:

  • One for Supplier A (goods)
  • One for Supplier B (freight/customs)

If the freight/customs costs are not known at PO creation use the ‚ÄúCreate Supplier Invoice ‚Äì Advanced‚Äù app, reference the original PO, enter the unplanned delivery cost in the Unplanned Delivery Costs section. You can also use Subsequent Debit to post these costs later

For freight/customs that affect inventory valuation, use the ‚ÄúManage Landed Costs‚Äù app, allocate non-merchandise costs post-GR, ensures accurate Moving Average Price (MAP) adjustment.

entry.title: SAP Service Cloud V2 Utilities Add-on - Extending Premise Replication with Custom Field - PART I
entry.content:
Introduction

This is the first blog in a series of 3, where I will show how to extend the Premise data replication from SAP S/4HANA to SAP Service Cloud V2 with a custom field. It is a simple process, and I have decided to split this in 3 blogs, given we are touching 3 different systems.

I plan to add a video covering the steps taken in this blog as well.

When completed there will be a new custom field displayed to the user in SAP Service Cloud V2 that has been passed as part data replication.

 

The steps and sequence to achieve the above are:

-  Adding the field to the payload send from SAP S/4HANA,

-  Adding the data to SAP Service Cloud V2, and use adaptation to show it on the view

-  Update the mapping in SAP Data Integration Suite

 

Extend the service and add data in SAP S/4HANA

To be able to pass additional data to SAP Service Cloud V2, two things need to happen in SAP S/4HANA:

  1. Extending the structure in the service with a custom field
  2. Adding logic to populate the field added to the service

 

Extending the structure of the service in SAP S/4HANA

Extending the service is done using transaction SE80 and then open the package ‚ÄòISU_C4C_PROXY‚Äô.

The service we will extend is: CLASCO_ISU_C4C_V2_PREM_CONNOBJ_REP‚Äô.

Right click on the PREMISE_CONNECTION_OBJECT and then select the options marked in red.

A prompt will ask for the name of the new element:

After accepting the name, all attributes for the element are displayed.

I changed the Minimum Occurs to 0 (zero) for this field not to be mandatory. The XSD Type is changed to ‚ÄòToken‚Äô to support the IFlow.

After saving and activating the service, the service is ready to carry the field.

 

Adding logic to populate the field.

The next step is adding the logic to pass a value for the field.

In transaction SE24, we open the CL_ISU_C4C_V2_TECH_OBJ_REP class.

The method we will extend is the CONN_OBJ_PROXY_DATA.

The logic for the extension is done in a BADI, and the simplest way to navigate to this one is to open the source code of the method and click in the name of the BADI.

I will not cover how to activate a BADI, this is covered by help information and other blogs.

Here we see the methods available for the BADI and the one we will extend here is the one for Connection Object.

A small comment ‚Äì since I am basically passing a test value, it would not matter if I used the method for Connection Object or Premise, since the structure created for the payload is the same. The difference between extending the method for Connection Object or Premise is what data is available as part of the import parameters.

The below line assigns a value to field in the structure we created earlier:

For this I created a sample. Instead of passing a fixed value to the attribute I am at random passing one or the other parameter. This is where the actual logic for finding the data should be added.

While not recommended for data consistency, it is also possible to take a value from an existing attribute and changes this before sending it to SAP Service Cloud V2.

In Appendix I have put a copy of the above code.

 

Testing the logic in SAP S/4HANA

The simplest way to test if the above work is to make a change to a premise and then look at the payload in message monitoring (transaction SRT_UTIL), and then select Message Monitoring.

 

 

With the above the SAP S/4HANA steps are completed and the next step after testing the field is successfully passed, will be to extend the Premise object in SAP Service Cloud V2 and add the field to the Premise view.

 

APPENDIX

Sample code the method 

 method IF_ISU_C4C_V2_TECH_OBJS_REPL~CONN_OBJ_ADJUST_DATA.

 DATA: zz_roof_type TYPE c length 20.

**** SAMPLE CODE FOR POPULATING FIELD  ****

DATA: lv_random TYPE i.

CALL FUNCTION 'QF05_RANDOM_INTEGER'
  EXPORTING
    ran_int_min = 1
    ran_int_max = 2
  IMPORTING
    ran_int     = lv_random.

 IF lv_random = 1.
   zz_roof_type = 'Not Solar Relevant'.
 else.
   zz_roof_type = 'Solar Relevant'.
 endif.

******************************************



    c_conn_obj_data-premise_connection_object-z_roof_type = zz_roof_type.

  endmethod.

entry.title: Re: aw01n shows a problem
entry.content:
ANLC is the summary table for asset values per fiscal year. The field KANSW holds cumulative acquisition and production costs. AW01N pulls its upper section (planned values) from ANLC, and the lower section (transactions) from ANEP. If KANSW is zero or missing, AW01N will show no starting value for that year, even if depreciation postings exist.

To your question, Can 2018 Still Be Corrected? the answer is yes but with limitations. Here's what you can do:

  • Run transaction AJRW (Fiscal Year Change) for 2018 again. This can rebuild missing entries in ANLC if the asset values exist in ANEP. Ensure that depreciation areas and charts of depreciation are correctly configured.
  • If the issue is due to missing texts or depreciation area configuration, SAP Note 380190 recommends running RACORR14. This program checks and copies missing entries from alternate charts of depreciation.
  • Finally and most importantly, if the issue is purely cosmetic in AW01N and does not affect accounting or depreciation, you may choose to leave 2018 as-is and document the anomaly. However, if reporting or audit requirements demand correction, AJRW and RACORR14 are your safest options.

entry.title: Re: Multi-Tenant Audit Logging Fails for Subscriber Tenan...
entry.content:
Hello @agustino 

Thanks for the additional context. I‚Äôve actually come across this exact scenario in one of my recent CAP projects. When using centralized audit logging in the provider tenant, the key is not to inject the x-zid header manually or rely on CAP‚Äôs default behaviour to do so. The log2restv2 logger attempts by default to obtain a token for the subscriber tenant and this fails because the Audit Log Service is not bound there.

What we did was to ensure we logged in with the provider tenant‚Äôs credentials. I also suggest removing remove any x-zid header or override the logger context, if necessary, In your CAP logic. Then, make use of the tenant (subscriberID) API on the audit logger just for tagging the event with the right subscriber, but let the token still come from the provider‚Äôs XSUAA. By doing that, you will be complying with SAP‚Äôs recommendation for centralized logging events are tagged per tenant, but authorization and logging all route through the provider‚Äôs service binding.

Hope this provides the desired solution.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: SAPFPAYM not triggered automatically after F110 / Man...
entry.content:
The fact that your payment run completes successfully but the DME file is not automatically generated points to a missing or misconfigured link in the Printout/Data Medium setup.

Go to transaction FBZP ‚Üí Payment Methods in Company Code, select your payment method, in the Printout/Data Medium tab, ensure Program SAPFPAYM is assigned (not just RFFOAVIS_FPAYM). Assign a variant for SAPFPAYM that includes Payment run date and ID, Output control settings (e.g., ‚ÄúData Medium Exchange‚Äù checked). If SAPFPAYM is not listed, you may need to manually add it via customizing or use OBPM4 to define variants.

Use transaction OBPM4 to assign the correct variant for SAPFPAYM. Create or adjust the variant used for your payment method. Ensure the variant includes Payment run date and ID as dynamic parameters, Output to File System or TemSe as needed, Data Medium Exchange checkbox enabled.  Check SAP Note 984462 which explains how SAPFPAYM_SCHEDULE uses OBPM4 variants to trigger SAPFPAYM automatically.

In F110, before executing the payment run go to the Printout/Data Medium tab, Ensure the correct variant for SAPFPAYM is selected. Check the box for ‚ÄúStart Immediately‚Äù to trigger the print program.

Troubleshooting tips

entry.title: Re: How to add fields to LSMW Standard Batch Input
entry.content:
Hi @ABS21 

Thank you for your follow-up.

To your first question, it's not possible to add custom fields via the IBIPBDCD structure in standard LSMW for object. The reason behind this is, IBIPBDCD is designed to support a fixed set of SAP-delivered fields for batch input purposes and cannot be extended to include custom fields or Z-fields. You would require a custom development to achieve this.

For your second question, please note, fields from the 'Service Specification' screen, such as Net Price, are not supported by standard LSMW for task lists. The standard batch input object doesn't navigate into that screen, which is why the Net Price remains empty after upload. You have the possibility to Create a custom LSMW recording of transaction IA01/IA11 that includes the required screens and fields. This allows screen-by-screen control but might be sensitive to layout changes and screen sequence.

If you want to consider direct table updates, only do so if absolutely necessary and if your organization allows it but inconsistencies might happen.

Unfortunately, LSMW in its standard form is limited when it comes to advanced UI scenarios like Service Specifications.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Test Data Refresh service request on SAP for Me
entry.content:
Spoiler
Say goodbye to ticket hassles! Test Data Refresh requests just got easier ‚Äî now available directly via SAP for Me. Enjoy a guided, streamlined experience with full tracking and visibility. Check out the demo and simplify your next request!

We received a lot of feedback from our Test Data Refresh users and requesters of the service. One obvious point was the way of requesting via tickets is not the most elegant way.

So, we took your feedback for grant, and we are now happy to announce that we made available a guided and more convenient approach for the request of a Test Data Refresh service:

Test Data Refresh service request is now available via SAP for Me

With this new process you can manage all interaction via the central SAP for Me environment, and you do not need to handle all communication with incidents. This also includes a better overview of the history, status tracking and all benefits from SAP for Me can be used.

Now get ready and have a look at the demo to get familiar with the new process to request your next Test Data Refresh run:

 

Good to know for your next service request:

  • All communication on service requests (updates, action-items) are visible within SAP for Me communication tab. Any change will trigger automatically an email sent to your account.  
  • Ensure that you execute the ‚ÄúHandle your Extension‚Äù-App and set your settings early enough. Have a look at this great HYE blog post from @sophsommerrock 
  • Execute the ‚ÄúCheck your Readiness‚Äù app beforehand and regularly that all is set for the service execution. Issues realized on short notice could lead to a cancellation of the service.
  • Always open the service request on time, recommended at least one week before planned Test Data Refresh execution and ensure a healthy Readiness Check via the ‚ÄúCheck your Readiness‚Äù app.
  • In case you overcome any issues during the service request, please open a ticket on CA-DT-TDR.

A comprehensive explanation is available at our documentation in our help portal: Service Request

Let us know your thoughts, feedback and improvement ideas.

Happy requesting üòä - your Test Data Refresh team

PS: Always check our our TDR community page: https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/s4hana-cloud-test-data-refresh

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori Launchpad
entry.content:
This second post in my series gives an overview of user experience innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and the SAP Fiori launchpad which are now generally available. It covers Joule and many AI-assisted UX innovations, new collaboration capabilities as well as improvements in details. The next post will cover additional innovations available to customers for beta testing.

Users in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can query SAP Analytics Cloud directly via Joule. Read about this and more in the first blog post introducing the series and providing general information about Joule and central entry points and services:

  • SAP UX Q3/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 1: AI, Joule, SAP Build Work Zone, SAP Mobile Start.

This post gives an overview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition UX innovations in these areas:

  • SAP Fiori launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency
  • My Home
  • AI-Assisted UX Features
  • Collaboration: Integration of To Dos for Situations in Microsoft Teams
  • UX Improvements in Details

Many of the UX improvements in details are enabled by our UI framework (SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements) and hence also available to customers and partners developing their own applications. Note however that the enabled AI-assisted features are only available for extensions built directly on the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition system.

Below you‚Äôll see those AI innovations with largest impact on user experience, but you can get a more comprehensive overview of the latest AI innovations in these blog posts:

  • Highlights of the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release.
  • Exploring AI and next-gen Cloud ERP innovations in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.
  • Try the latest AI features in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 (covering the AI-assisted features enabled by our UI framework).

 

SAP Fiori Launchpad and Design Updates for Suite Consistency

We have made design improvements which are relevant for a consistent user experience across the entire SAP Business Suite, and which are now available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508. As I mentioned in my April blog post Upcoming Design Updates for the SAP Business Suite (SAP Fiori for Web), consistency of the user experience across the various applications used by a user is an important part of overall usability, helping users to feel confident and at ease when using a suite of products ‚Äì no unexpected surprises.

In this section, we‚Äôll look at four design updates provided by the SAP Fiori launchpad, as well as examples of the new design for illustrations, and some updates for launchpad administrators:

  • Navigation menu: Side navigation
  • Updated shell bar
  • Updated user menu
  • Updated notifications
  • New illustrations design
  • Update for administrators

Navigation Menu: Side Navigation

Many SAP products already offer a navigation menu on the left of the screen, a pattern already familiar to many people. Hence we have decided to apply that approach to navigation across the SAP Business Suite in upcoming releases.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the side navigation is displayed as an overlay, as you can see in Figure 1. It gives you direct access to your favorite apps, either directly or via the folders you have created. It also gives you direct access to your Spaces and Pages. The previously available menu to access all your spaces and pages along with personalization options is available via the entry ‚ÄúAll Spaces‚Äù at the bottom of the menu.

A big benefit of this new navigation menu is that you can now access your favorite apps directly from any application. Previously, you would have to return to My Home and then click on your favorite app, now you can access it directly from the menu, as shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1: The new navigation menu, opened up from the new shell bar, showing direct access to Favourite Apps, My Spaces and All Spaces. Alt Text: an image showing a list of sales orders and on the left a pop-over with a navigation menu with the sections already mentioned. Below the ‚ÄúFavourite App‚Äù eight apps are listed as well as two folders for favorite apps, plus the folder ‚ÄúInsights‚Äù for the insight tiles.

New Shell Bar ‚Äì need to switch it on!

The new shell bar design for the SAP Business Suite is available for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. The immediately visible difference is that now the product name is displayed to the right of the SAP Logo, in this case ‚ÄúS/4HANA Cloud‚Äù as you can see at the top of Figure 1. The logo and the name are all contained within a clickable area, which brings the user to the start page (i.e. My Home).

The new shell bar enables the next two design updates to the user menu and to notifications.

By default, after upgrading, the old shell bar will be shown, with the new navigation menu. We advise that you check any test automation and RPA (Robotic Process Automation) you may have before switching on the new shell bar, since you may need to make some adjustments ‚Äì in particular if you log off at the end of a test.

You can switch on the new shell bar via the Activate New Features application, with the feature ‚Äú/UI2/SHELL_BAR_TOGGLE‚Äù, which is planned to become available mid-August 2025.

Updated User Menu

The new user menu design shown in Figure 2 provides more space for the avatar of the user, and provides more space between items for easier selection. The settings are always at the top as the first entry, and the ‚ÄúSign Out‚Äù option is separated from the actual navigation options in the list, to make it easier to find.

Figure 2: Updated design of user menu and notifications. Alt Text: On the left an image of the previous user menu and the updated user menu. On the right an image of the updated notifications list, showing four notifications in the group ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù, each with a title, two lines of description and a line with the data and a ‚Äúmore‚Äù link.

Updated Notifications Design

The new simplified design of notifications shown on the right in Figure 2  fits better with the overall design of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, and provides simplier interactions. By default notifications are sorted by date, with grouping by ‚ÄúToday‚Äù, ‚ÄúYesterday‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Week‚Äù, ‚ÄúLast Month‚Äù. Users can also choose to sort by importance.

New Illustrations Design

We have modernized the design of our illustrations, and also made them easier to understand. Figure 3 shows two examples ‚Äì one for indicating that something went wrong (the fallen ice cream cone), one for search, with an example of where the search illustration is used when opening a list report application without any filter values defined.

Figure 3: Examples of new illustrations. Alt Text: On the left top three different size illustrations showing an ice cream cone fallen on the ground; bottom left an illustration of a globe with a magnifying glass, representing ‚Äúsearch‚Äù. On the right an image of a list report showing the search illustration since no data has been selected.

Update for Administrators of SAP Fiori Launchpad

Hiding of Empty Spaces and Pages

Empty Spaces and Pages are now automatically hidden from users. Until now this was an option which administrators needed to switch on, now it is on by default.

You might be asking how a space or page could be empty? The apps which a user sees on a page on the SAP Fiori launchpad, and the pages which appear in a space, depend on a user‚Äôs authorizations. This can lead to a page being defined in such a way that certain users are not authorized to use any of the apps therein; similarly, a space can end up not having any pages available to a user. Now, if this happens, any such empty pages or spaces are hidden from the user, rather than being shown empty.

Redesign of Apps for Managing Spaces and Pages

Up until now, the apps ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Spaces‚Äù and ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Pages‚Äù distinguished between entries which could be edited within a given tenant and entries which could only be used as templates when creating new spaces or pages. The editable ones were listed in the tab ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù, the others in the tab ‚ÄúPredefined‚Äù.

Our customers gave us feedback that this was in fact confusing, because a page which was listed as ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù in a non-productive tenant and which was transferred to a productive tenant became ‚ÄúPredefined‚Äù there, i.e. it was not listed under ‚ÄúCustomer-Created‚Äù despite it being customer-created.

Now, the design has been changed, with two tabs for editable entities (spaces or pages) and non-editable ones. For example, in the app ‚ÄúManage Launchpad Pages‚Äù, the tabs are called ‚ÄúPages‚Äù and ‚ÄúPage Templates‚Äù, as shown in Figure 4. No matter what tenant you are in, you cannot change or edit page templates, you can only use them to create new pages. The same applies to spaces in the Manage Launchpad Spaces app.

Figure 4: The redesigned app Manage Launchpad Pages with Tabs for ‚ÄúPages‚Äù and ‚ÄúPage Templates‚Äù. Alt Text: image shows an extract of the app showing the two tabs.

For more information about the visual updates, and what‚Äôs new, check out:

  • Blog post: Transforming User Experience: SAP Fiori Launchpad adopts the latest SAP Design System updates.
  • What‚Äôs New: SAP Fiori launchpad in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

 

My Home

My Home is proving very popular with users, and we hope to make it even more so with the innovations in the 2508 release:

  • The salutation bar, welcoming users and providing interesting options.
  • Recap ‚Äì summarizing what changed since you last logged on.
  • Manage News application for customer-specific news.
  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insights cards
    (this is covered in the next section AI-Assisted UX Innovations)

We are also providing two new features for beta-testing, AI-assisted smart personalization for applications and AI-assisted smart solution for situations in My Home, which I will showcase in part 3 in this series of blog posts.

Salutation Bar in My Home

The new salutation bar shown in Figure 5 welcomes users to the system, and gives them direct access to My Home settings as well as to the new Recap feature explained below. Optionally, you can set the system up to let business users see what‚Äôs next on their calendar. (Not shown in Figure 5. Use communication arrangement SAP_COM_0887 to set enable it).

Figure 5: The new salutation bar in My Home, showing the welcome text ‚ÄúHi Barbara, Great to see you again!‚Äù and the beta AI option ‚ÄúAdd Content‚Äù, plus the options ‚ÄúRecap‚Äù and ‚ÄúMy Home Settings‚Äù. Alt Text: Image shows My Home with a new dark. Blue bar just below the header, with today‚Äôs date top left, below which in larger font ‚ÄúHi Barbara, Great to see you again!‚Äù is written. On the right of the bar three buttons are shown: the AI button ‚ÄúAdd Content‚Äù, ‚ÄúRecap‚Äù, and ‚ÄúMy Home Settings‚Äù.

Recap

With recap, you can get a quick overview of what has changed on My Home since you last logged on: new or updated tasks, situations and insight cards. This saves you a lot of time, since you don‚Äôt have to scan everything manually, and ensures that you are all caught up quickly ‚Äì and don‚Äôt miss any important changes. What is great about it is that it is visual, showing before and after images of insight cards ‚Äì you can see an example in Figure 6, or watch it in action in this video:

  • Video: Recap Feature of My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (0:55 min.)

Figure 6: Recap in My Home, showing a change in an insight card, where one additional quotation has expired, and one additional quotation will expire after a week. Alt Text: a popover on top of My Home, with a ‚ÄúSummary‚Äù section on the left containing three items ‚ÄúTasks‚Äù, ‚ÄúSituations‚Äù, and ‚ÄúCards‚Äù, with ‚ÄúCards‚Äù selected. The right shows two tabs, ‚ÄúChanged (3)‚Äù (selected) and ‚ÄúRemoved (2)‚Äù, below which a card marked ‚Äúold‚Äù with a horizontal bar chart is shown on the left, and the same card with updated data marked ‚Äúnew‚Äù on the right.

Manage News Application

I‚Äôm glad to announce that administrators can now easily create their own news to be displayed on My Home, using the new Manage News application. Figure 7 shows the start page of the application, listing news articles.

You can specify title, subtitle and main text, a background image, the start and end dates, as well as categorizing and targeting the news for specific groups of users or roles.

Figure 7: Manage News application. Alt Text: Screenshot of the Manage News application, showing a filter bar and a list of two news articles with their title, subtitle, footer text, criticality, status ‚Äúpublished‚Äù and publish start and end dates.

To get a better impression of how it works, watch this video:

  • Video: Manage News Application in My Home for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (2:00 min.)

You can find out more about these My Home innovations here:

  • My Home in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 - What's new?.
  • My Home documentation.

 

AI-Assisted User Experience

When AI is embedded directly into the application UI to give users a better user experience, as opposed to being accessed via the Joule window, we talk about ‚ÄúAI-Assisted User Experience‚Äù.

In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508, we distinguish between AI base features and premium features:

  • Base features are free of charge, and only require that the customer signs the SAP AI Terms, which can be done via this link.
  • Premium features require SAP AI Units to be in place. Those listed here also require Joule Premium for Financial Management. Customers can activate this via SAP for Me -> Portfolio & Products -> Business AI.

The following are now generally available as base features:

  • AI-assisted enterprise search (which was in beta testing with the 2502 release). See below for more details.
  • AI-assisted easy filter.
  • AI-assisted smart summarization.

The latter two were generally available under limited promotion with the 2502 release, now they are generally available out of the box ‚Äì no need to sign up to the limited promotion. To find out more about these two, look at my blog post:

  • SAP UX Q1/2025 Update ‚Äì Part 2: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2502 and SAP Fiori Launchpad

The following premium feature is now generally available:

  • AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insight cards.
    See below for more details.

AI-Assisted Enterprise Search

You can now use natural language in the search field available at the top of every screen in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, making it even easier to benefit from powerful enterprise search capabilities. With enterprise search, you can find the information you need directly, without having to specify the name of the application ‚Äì as you can see in Figure 8. This is available out of the box as a base feature.

Figure 8: AI-assisted enterprise search, showing how you can easily find business data directly using natural language. Alt Text: ALT Text: A short video showing how a user can enter in the search field in the shell header bar ‚ÄúShow me all sales orders with net value greater than 5000 eur‚Äù and get a corresponding list sales orders. The user than adds the text ‚Äúthat are in process‚Äù resulting in a list with fewer results.

Watch the full video:

  • Video:  AI-Assisted Enterprise Search in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition  (0:48 min.)

AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Insight Cards

With this premium feature, you can now use natural language to add an insight card to My Home. You just have to describe what information you want to see on the card, and the system will create the card for you. We ensure that the user is in control by first showing a preview of the card, allowing the user to either confirm, or rephrase the request. Figure 9 shows the kind of text you can use, and figure 10 gives you an idea of the interaction flow.

Figure 9: AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insight cards, showing an example prompt and the resulting card. Alt Text: a popover ‚ÄúAdd Insights Cards‚Äù above My Home is shown, with a text entry field on the left containing the AI prompt ‚Äúcreate a card showing sales orders in overall status open and delivery block status blocked with fields sold-to-party, requested delivery date and net value‚Äù, below that an AI ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù and a ‚ÄúClear all‚Äù button, below that some sample queries, on the right the card preview showing ‚ÄúOpen Sales Orders‚Äù with sub-title ‚ÄúWith Delivery Block‚Äù.

 

Figure 10: AI-assisted smart personalization of My Home for insight cards in action. Alt Text: a short video showing the prompt from Figure 9 being entered, and the card being generated and added to the Insights section of My Home.

Watch the full video:

  • Video:  AI-Assisted Smart Personalization of My Home for Insights Cards in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition  (0:54 min.)

AI-Assisted Financial Business Insights

Users in Finance now benefit from AI-generated analysis and summaries built into the following review booklets:

  • Cost Centers Review Booklet
  • Group Finanical Statements Review Booklet
  • Project Financial Booklet ‚Äì Professional Services

Watch this video to get an overview for the cost centers review booklet:

  • Video: AI-Assisted Financial Business Insights (1:20 minutes)

Simplified Asset Accounting with SAP Business AI

With Joule and AI embedded in the applications, asset accountants can get their work done more easily now, with:

  • AI-assisted asset creation with Joule.
  • Easy to understand AI-generated natural language explanations of depreciation keys.
  • AI-generated value calculation insights.

Figure 11: AI-generated asset valuation explanation, after the user clicked on the AI-button ‚ÄúExplain Key Figures‚Äù. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a table summarizing the asset valuation, with an AI button ‚ÄúExplain Key Figures‚Äù in the table heading. Below the table a section ‚ÄúExplain Key Figures‚Äù is shown, with a text explaining how the depreciation is calculated.

Have a look at this video to see all three of these in action:

  • Video: Simplify Asset Accounting with SAP Business AI and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (3:25 minutes).

 

Collaboration: Integration of To Dos for Situations in Microsoft Teams

In addition to being able to process To Dos for tasks directly in Microsoft Teams (as I featured in my February blog post), you can now also process To Dos for Business Situations directly in Microsoft Teams.

This means that you get notified in your Teams activity feed about new Business Situations, and you can process Business Situations in place, without having to leave Teams, as you can see in Figure 12.

Figure 12: To Dos for Business Situations are available via Activities in Microsoft Teams. Alt Text: Two screenshots are shown, the top one shows an row of Situation cards in My Home, the bottom one shows the Activity view in Teams, with the activity ‚ÄúSituations in SAP S/4HANA‚Äù and sub-text ‚ÄúThere are 9 situations for you‚Äù selected on the left, and the right two thirds of the screen showing a list with the same situations as shown in My Home.

To enable this, you need to install the SAP S/4HANA for Microsoft Teams app.

For further information:

  • Video: To Dos in Microsoft Teams (1:00)
  • Documentation: Integrating Microsoft Teams.

 

UX Improvements in Details

The details matter for a great user experience, so we continue to gather user feedback and work on improving these details, which though relatively small can have a big impact on user satisfaction. Let‚Äôs have a look at the highlights of what we are improving with the 2508 release.

Improved performance for scrolling in grid tables

Our engineers have done some magic so that now scrolling is very fast in grid tables, which are the table type typically used for working with large volumes of data.

Why do I call it magic? Well, modern web-based UIs have the UI layer running in the browser, managing direct user interactions, and calling services in the backend to get and update data. However, if you are working with a list of say over 100,000 items, you would have to wait quite a long time when starting the application until all items have been loaded into the browser. Hence we only load a certain number to start with, such as 100. This however means that when a user scrolls beyond the 100 which have been loaded, additional data needs to be fetched from the backend, which slows down scrolling. Now, our engineers have found a way to minimize this effect to almost zero, so that you have fast scrolling all the time ‚Äì magic!

Figure 13: Performance improvement for scrolling in grid tables. Alt Text: a short video showing scrolling through a grid table.

Whenever the threshold is reached and more data needs to be loaded, there is a very short delay, with the progress indicator being shown for a few milliseconds, as you can see in Figure 13. In most cases, this is completely negligible. Nevertheless, we do also provide customers the option to change the number of entries loaded by default when the application is started. This is useful if a customer knows that, for a certain application, the number of entries will not exceed 2.000 for example. Then they can set the threshold to 2.000, which means that the application will take a little bit longer to load first time around, but then scrolling will be instantaneous for all the data. Figure 14 shows the UI for doing this, as part of UI adaptation. The ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù determines the maximum number of entries loaded when the application is started, the ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù determines the maximum number that are loaded during scrolling if new entries need to be fetched.

Figure 14: UI adaptation to determine the threshold determining the maximum number of entries loaded in a table when an application is started. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúConfigure Table‚Äù with two new fields ‚ÄúThreshold‚Äù, being edited with the value 3000, and ‚ÄúScroll Threshold‚Äù, containing the value 300.

Sort or Group Tables by ID or Description

SAP Fiori apps display the ID and the description in the same column within a table, which provides a better experience than having them in two separate columns.

Now, we offer users a choice when sorting or grouping the table by a column which contains both ID and description: they can choose to do this by ID or by description. As you can see in Figure 15, this selection is very intuitive. The example shows what it looks like when sorting by Company Code. At the bottom of the table you see an entry ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù, where the Company Code (the ID) is 1710 and the Company Name (the Description) is ‚ÄúBestRun US‚Äù. In the popover ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section, the row of icons next to Company Code and Company Name indicate that currently no sorting is active, with the option to sort either bei Code or by Name ascending or descending.

Figure 15: Sort or group tables by ID (in this case Company Code) or by Description (Company Name) when both are displayed together in one column . Alt Text: A screenshot of part of the Manage Journal Entries app, with a list of journal entries and a pop-over ‚ÄúColumn Settings‚Äù with two sections ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù and ‚ÄúGroup By‚Äù. The ‚ÄúSort By‚Äù section has two lines, ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù and ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù, and offers three buttons with icons for each of these, representing ‚Äúno sorting‚Äù, ‚Äúascending‚Äù, ‚Äúdescending‚Äù.

Hiding Description Fields in List of Fields in Table Settings

For tables as above where ID and description are displayed in one column, technically, the ID and description are stored in two different fields. Until now, when users personalize the table, both the ID and the description were listed in the list of columns, which confused some users.

Now, we have addressed this by providing the option to hide the descriptions (see Figure 16), and hence simplifying personalization. This option is on by default, i.e. the description fields are automatically hidden now.

Figure 16: Description fields can be hidden from the list of fields shown when personalizing tables. Alt Text: A screenshot with a pop-over ‚ÄúView Settings‚Äù containing tabs ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù, ‚ÄúSort‚Äù, ‚ÄúFilter‚Äù, and a pop-over ‚ÄúFilters‚Äù with two options ‚ÄúHide descriptions‚Äù (selected) and ‚ÄúHide Unselected‚Äù (deselected) . ‚ÄúColumns‚Äù is selected and shows a list of columns with check marks. The third entry is ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù, followed by ‚ÄúCreated On‚Äù ‚Äì i.e. the description column ‚ÄúCompany Name‚Äù is not listed next to the ‚ÄúCompany Code‚Äù.

Key Users Can Rearrange ID and Description Within a Field or Column

SAP applications come with a standard arrangement of ID and description within a field or a column, based on user research. We have found that for financial users, it is usually best to have the ID first and the description in brackets: Company Code (Company Description), for example ‚Äú1710 (BestRun US)‚Äù as shown in Figure 15. For users in sales and logistics, it is usually best to have the name first and the ID in brackets: for example Customer Name (Customer ID), for example ‚ÄúUS Specialty Cycles 5 (USCU_S05)‚Äù as shown in Figure 1.

Now, key users can use UI adaptation to rearrange the order for a given application. Doing this change applies then to all occurrences of the field in the application, i.e. the filter bar, the table or in a form on an object page.

Table Grouping and/or ‚ÄúShow more per row‚Äù State can be Shared

If a user personalizes a table by grouping entries by one of the fields, such as the date, this grouping is persisted when sharing the link with a colleage: when the colleague opens the application with the link, they see they same grouping applied.

Similarly, if ‚Äúshow more per row‚Äù was selected by the user before sharing the link, the recipient will also see more information per row upon opening the application via the link. This information is also stored when saving a view of a table.

Documentation of Keyboard Shortcuts within Applications

Power users are often quicker when only using the keyboard, rather than switching back and forth between keyboard and mouse ‚Äì but only if they know all the relevant keyboard shortcuts. With the 2508 release we provide information about available keyboard shortcuts directly where you need them, in the context of the application. By selecting ‚ÄúKeyboard Shortcuts‚Äù in the user menu, a new window appears explaining all the available shortcuts for the application area currently in focus. If you click on a different part of the application, or navigate somewhere else, then the window showing the available shortcuts is updated immediately for the new context.

Figure 17 shows an example for Manage Journal Entries, where the focus is currently on the filter bar. Clicking on the the table results in many more shortcuts being shown, for example for the arrow keys for moving up and down etc., as shown in Figure 18.

Figure 17: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the filter bar. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app ‚ÄúManage Journal Entries‚Äù with the focus on the filter bar, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, ‚ÄúGlobal Shortcuts‚Äù and ‚ÄúGeneric Keyboard Interactions‚Äù.

Figure 18: In-context documentation of keyboard shortcuts, for the table. Alt Text: A screenshot of the app ‚ÄúManage Journal Entries‚Äù with the focus on the table, with a second window on the right containing Keyboard Shortcuts in two groups, ‚ÄúGlobal Shortcuts‚Äù and ‚ÄúJournal Entries (43,854)‚Äù. The latter contains descriptions for shortcuts for the table, such as the arrow up, down, left, right keys, or using ‚ÄúCmd + D‚Äù to delete.

These are the highlights of our changes in details. For the full list, have a look at the What‚Äôs New Viewer:

  • UX in What‚Äôs New Viewer for  SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.

 

Continued soon with an overview of new UX Innovations for Beta Testing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508

I hope you enjoyed this second part, covering what is now generally available with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 and SAP Fiori launchpad. I will post part three in the next few days, covering exciting new UX innovations available for beta testing with the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release.

Do keep posting your experiences and recommendations yourself in the SAP Community, with the SAP Fiori and/or the User Experience tag! In case you are wondering how to get a list of the most recent blog posts on SAP Fiori and User Experience in our new SAP Community, use these links:

  • Latest blog posts on SAP Fiori in the SAP Community.
  • Latest blog posts on User Experience in the SAP Community.

entry.title: Issue with Deep Entity Set After OData Service Regeneration
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

After regenerating our OData services, we're encountering errors related to the deep entity set. Has anyone faced similar issues or found a reliable way to resolve them?

Any insights or suggestions would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: Running Finance Facility in TRM
entry.content:
Dear Treasury Experts!

We are handling different short-term and long-term loans through interest rate instruments and working perfectly. But how to manage the running finance facility in TRM as no amount is being credited to bank account and used to pay vendors etc. .How to handle these RF loans in TRM? 

 

Regards.

entry.title: Re: SAP CPQ Quote 2.0 Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud...
entry.content:
Hello @Leo_Delgado 

To integrate a SAP CPQ Quote 2.0 into SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition as a Sales Contract or Sales Order, the standard approach is via the Sales Order (A2X) API.
Relevant API:

API_SALES_ORDER_SRV
SAP API Business Hub ‚Äì Sales Order (A2X)
This OData API allows CPQ to create or update Sales Orders directly in S/4HANA Cloud.

Note: If you intend to integrate as a Sales Contract (not Sales Order), use:
API_SALES_CONTRACT_SRV 
SAP API ‚Äì Sales Contract (A2X)

Ensure proper communication arrangement is set up in S/4HANA Public Cloud for the relevant API scenario (e.g., SAP_COM_0109 for Sales Order).

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Change SI Unit
entry.content:
To change the SI unit from KG to a newly created unit "1K" in SAP, you‚Äôll need to follow a few key steps. However, it's important to note that SI units (Standard International Units) are predefined in SAP and cannot be changed directly. Instead, you can create a new unit of measure (UoM) and define conversion rules from the SI unit to your custom unit.

Go to Transaction Code CUNI, create a new unit "1K", define its dimension (e.g., weight), set the conversion factor from KG to 1K (e.g., 1K = 1000 KG or whatever your logic is). In CUNI, under the "Conversions" tab, set the numerator and denominator for conversion between KG and 1K. Example if 1K = 1000 KG, then Numerator = 1000 and Denominator = 1

entry.title: 'Maintain Form Templates' Language Translations
entry.content:
Hello Gurus,

We have a requirement were in we need to provide 'Italian' Translation for Standard Form 'IT_FXDAST_REG' and this is a 'Fragment Usage' based AdobeForm and not a Normal AdobeForm.

Below are the queries/observations I have while doing the analysis for this requirement.

1.) While checking this Form in Fiori app 'Maintain Form Templates' it's observed that this Form is shipped with 'Italian' Translations.

Hence, we tried running the Standard Fiori app which indeed triggers this Form with 'Language' set as Italian in the Fiori User Settings, but it didn't work and the output was rendered in Original English language only.

Additionally, we also noticed that for this Form ( and even if we try to Copy this Form to a ZFORM object ) in the SFP TCode the 'Translation' option always shows as disabled. So, this and the above observation made me conclude that for 'Fragment Usage' based AdobeForms the regular Translation mechanism won't work as it used to work for Normal AdobeForms i.e. SE63 Translation where-in we will maintain Translations for a Form and based on the Logon language the Translations gets applied.

2.) Referred SAP documentation https://help.sap.com/doc/saphelp_nw75/7.5.5/en-US 

And also referred a similar post, https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/maintain-for-template-translation-export-or-tranport-or-manual-modifictaion/qaq-p/12375689 

Does this conclude that we need to Create/Maintain FORMs for each and every Language ?

I downloaded the Italian Translation version Form Layout as highlighted in Point 1.) above and created a Custom Form using SFP Transaction by using the 'Uploading layout' option and used the .xdp file which got downloaded previously. And now I could see all the Italian Translations available for the Static Texts by default.

My question, is the above understandings/observations correct ? And Indeed would we need to maintain individual forms for such cases in each and every languages?

Thanks,

Sijin

entry.title: Re: remove comma from the last line on output file in the...
entry.content:
Hi @user116 

Thank you for your follow-up and clarification.

I agree the second option is better in this case. The best approach would be to clean up the file after generation but before it's picked up by LMS. I would advice to use a post-processing script or middleware (like SAP Cloud Integration or a small shell script on your SFTP server) to remove the last empty line or the trailing comma. For example if you are using Unix/Linux, a sed command can do the job. This removes a line that only contains a comma at the end of the file. However, if you‚Äôre using SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) between SF and LMS, you can add a Groovy script step in the integration flow.

This will make sure the file is formatted correctly before it reaches the desired LMS, avoiding errors due to invalid structure.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to decide "Do not post data in ERP" in /SCWM/ISU...
entry.content:
The functionality of Post to ERP (Do not tick ‚ÄúDo not post data in ERP‚Äù) is if you want the stock to be reflected in both EWM and ERP (Inventory Management). This is typical for initial stock uploads during go-live or data migration. The system will create material documents in ERP (e.g., movement type 561).

The functionality of Post Only in EWM (Tick ‚ÄúDo not post data in ERP‚Äù) is if you want to upload stock only in EWM, without affecting ERP. Useful for testing, simulation, or temporary decoupling of systems. ERP will not reflect the stock, but will reflect only in EWM.

So the decision to post inventory data in ERP (ECC or S/4HANA) or only in EWM depends on your business scenario and system setup.

entry.title: Re: Shared Resource Scenario in PPDS
entry.content:
Hi @Debasis_Nanda 

Thank you for the details.

Evaluating from your details that your packing line runs for 8 hours per order, but your shared resource is modelled with a 24-hour capacity shows a mismatch. I believe this mismatch is due to the way the shared resource‚Äôs bucket capacity and consumption duration are defined.

Consider defining the usage of the shared resource per operation with a duration that matches the packing activity in your PDS. This means the hopper resource will only be "blocked" for those 8 hours per operation, not for the full 24 hours. You can do this by assigning the duration-based usage in the secondary resource tab of the operation. This should not just be the quantity but also the time window they are required.

Please also make sure you activate finite scheduling on both primary and secondary resources so that the system respects the capacity constraints properly across packing lines.

If your packing rates differ per product, consider modelling this using PDS variants or setup groups, so each product gets the appropriate hopper consumption and duration without hardcoding it.

I hope this helps.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Scan Multiple Products in Source area with RF During...
entry.content:
Hi @MahmoudElshall 

Private Cloud opens up more flexibility for you.

I suggest you firstly, create a custom RF transaction to scan all source HUs first, then scan destinations in sequence. Then make use of BADI like /SCWM/EX_RF_PTS_STEP to control RF step flow and enable batching of source scans. You can optionally, build a Fiori or ITS mobile app tailored to this logic. In the short term, I would suggest you adjust your WOCR rules to group tasks by bin location and reduce movement.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: EWM Replenishment with HU Types and Packing Step ‚Äì Er...
entry.content:
Ensure your POSC configuration includes an intermediate storage type (e.g., packing station) before the final destination bin. In customizing: SCM Extended Warehouse Management ‚Üí Cross-Process Settings ‚Üí Storage Control ‚Üí Define Process-Oriented Storage Control. There define a storage process with steps like Remove from stock, Pack (intermediate storage type: packing workstation), Put away. This ensures the system routes the HU first to the packing station, and delays final bin validation until after repacking.

In the storage type configuration for the fixed bin go to SCM EWM ‚Üí Master Data ‚Üí Define Storage Type. Under Putaway Control, check HU Type Check is set to blank or allow broader HU types, Putaway Storage Control is enabled to defer bin validation until after POSC steps. This allows the system to create the initial WT without failing due to HU type mismatch.

SAP Note 2409948 recommends this BAdI /SCWM/EX_CORE_PTS_NBIN_NRM for similar mixed storage scenarios. You can programmatically bypass HU type validation during initial WT creation if POSC is active

entry.title: Re: Triggering SAP Build Process Automation Workflow from a Custom SAP Fiori Application
entry.content:
Thanks for idea validation. I am trying something along the lines:

CLASS zcl_workflow_proxy IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD start_workflow.
    DATA: lo_http_client  TYPE REF TO if_http_client,
          lv_url          TYPE string,
          lv_token        TYPE string,
          lv_payload      TYPE string,
          lv_result       TYPE string,
          lo_rest_client  TYPE REF TO cl_rest_http_client.

    " 1. Create the request body
    lv_payload = /ui2/cl_json=>serialize( data = is_input compress = abap_true ).

    " 2. Get token (mock, or use OAuth2 logic here)
    lv_token = 'Bearer YOUR_ACCESS_TOKEN'.

    " 3. Create HTTP client
    lv_url = 'https://api.workflow.sap.com/v1/workflow-instances'. " Replace with real
    cl_http_client=>create_by_url(
      EXPORTING url = lv_url
      IMPORTING client = lo_http_client
    ).

    " 4. Set headers
    lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = lv_token ).
    lo_http_client->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
    lo_http_client->request->set_method( 'POST' ).
    lo_http_client->request->set_cdata( lv_payload ).

    " 5. Send request
    lo_http_client->send( ).
    lo_http_client->receive( ).

    lv_result = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).

    " 6. Convert response to structure
    /ui2/cl_json=>deserialize(
      EXPORTING json = lv_result
      CHANGING data = rs_response
    ).
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

Just needs to add OAuth 2.0 handling by first calling */oauth/token and then consuming it in step 2. 

Then to call this in RAP action.

So far it seems it will work.

entry.title: Re: Shop Order Release error without ODS active
entry.content:
Hi!

 

First of all, it is not clear what active ODS means in the context of your question.

If "not active ODS database" means the ODS database itself, then formally SAP ME should not work without ODS database because it is a part of the solution architecture.

If "not active ODS database" means Audit Log being disabled, then Shop Order release should work without it. If it is an opposite case where you have Audit Log activated but there is some issue with ODS database, then you can try to deactivate Audit Log in System Setup Maintenance.

 

Regards,

Sergiy

entry.title: Re: Project Systems, Clear information on BoQs
entry.content:
SAP Best Practice is

  • Use Document Info Records (DIRs) to attach BoQ documents to WBS.
  • Maintain BoQ versions for change tracking.
  • Integrate with SAP MM and SAP SD for full procurement and billing flows.
  • Use Network Activities for detailed scheduling and resource planning.

BoQ Process in SAP PS is Create the project using CJ01 or Project Builder. Define WBS elements to represent project phases or deliverables. Prepare BoQ items manually or import from external systems. Link BoQ items to WBS elements. Use BoQ to plan costs in SAP PS. Assign planned costs to WBS elements using:

  • Easy Cost Planning
  • Unit Costing
  • Activity-Based Costing

Convert BoQ items into Purchase Requisitions or RFQs via MM integration. Vendor BoQ drives subcontractor selection and pricing. Monitor actual consumption vs. BoQ quantities. Use confirmations and goods receipts to track progress.

For Customer BoQ, generate billing based on milestones or progress. Use DP91 or Resource-Related Billing.

For Vendor BoQ, process vendor invoices and match against BoQ quantities.

Compare planned vs. actual costs and quantities. Analyze deviations in scope, rate, or execution.

entry.title: Why we created Open Resource Discovery
entry.content:
What is Open Resource Discovery?

Open Resource Discovery (ORD) is a protocol for application / service metadata publishing and discovery. It can be used as a foundation for metadata catalogs / marketplaces and runtime introspection of system landscape resources. For more information, have a look at the ORD Introduction.

Building a static API & Event Catalog

The origin of ORD was as a publishing channel to SAP Business Accelerator Hub - formerly known as SAP API Hub - the centralized catalog for the public APIs and events offered by SAP products and SAP‚Äôs partners.

SAP aspires to offer one central place where developers can browse and explore existing APIs and get the API contracts as opposed to a proliferation of disconnected API portals and catalogs per product. From the beginning, we needed to support multiple protocols like OData, plain REST and SOAP. Early in this project, we established the use of open industry standards, most notably OpenAPI as the common denominator to describe all REST-based APIs (incl. OData).

When putting many different protocols and metadata description formats into one catalog, it quickly becomes obvious that the catalog needs some reliably consistent information across them:

  • Description: Titles, (short) descriptions, links, tags, etc.
  • Lifecycle: Version, lifecycle status and timelines (beta, active, deprecated), successors for deprecated, changelog, etc.
  • Taxonomy: Assignment to vendors, products, industry taxonomy, etc.
  • Grouping: Which resources belong together, can be discovered together

The second challenge was to provide an easy, automated way to publish the API & Event metadata, including the shared information listed above.

In 2018-2019, this led to the first drafts of the ORD protocol, driven by the Business Accelerator Hub team. The idea was to define a Service Provider Interface (SPI) enabling applications to expose their metadata by describing themselves, as an application is the only reliable source of information about itself. ORD is entirely complementary to the metadata industry standards we were already using; it merely provides a discovery wrapper around them and adds some common shared information, taxonomy, and relationships to build a single catalog from many individual sources.

With the ORD API implemented, an application can now register itself on Business Accelerator Hub and the metadata can be crawled and published without manual intervention, thus streamlining the publishing process.

Understanding Customer System Landscapes (Runtime Introspection)

In 2020, the Open Resource Discovery specification moved ownership to SAP‚Äôs Cross-Product Alignment (CPA) team. We quickly realized the potential in this idea, also beyond publishing static metadata to Business Accelerator Hub.

In the SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP), we needed a better understanding of the runtime (customer) system landscapes, including API and event resources. Since many of SAP‚Äôs larger solutions are highly customizable and extensible, the challenge is that each tenant can be different: some APIs may not be activated, some may have field extensions, some may have been added by the customer. Since the metadata in Business Accelerator Hub is static, it can only document a generic baseline of what a customer could look like. To find out what has changed since the snapshot taken in Business Accelerator Hub, it has become necessary to inspect the metadata of the systems at runtime.

This runtime metadata can be very useful ‚Äì for example, when creating side-by-side extensions in BTP or SAP Build, the developers benefit from knowing the actual state of interfaces, so they can find them more quickly and safely build against them

We realized that the same protocol and interfaces can be used to do both: describe the static baseline metadata and its current state. Therefore, we generalized the ORD specification to work for both static and runtime metadata discovery and integrate it with the Unified Customer Landscape (UCL).

When generalizing the ORD standard, we defined some design goals ‚Äì one of which was that the standard should work not only for SAP but be more general-purpose, so that it can be adopted and used by other companies once we open-sourced it. After verifying that ORD works well in SAP production environments, we released v1.0 to general availability in 2021.

Support Adoption and Validation with Tooling

Developers and integrations rely on machine-readable, well documented API interfaces. To improve the overall experience, we need to ensure that we have 1) wide coverage of metadata existing resources and 2) decent quality, so that API metadata is useful, consistent, and reliable for human developers and machines alike.

To scale this across a large company like SAP, it‚Äôs essential to not only provide guidelines and specs ‚Äì we also need to make it easy to adopt the metadata approach and have a quick validation / feedback loop.

For the ease of adoption, the obvious solution is to build ORD support right into the frameworks, like the ABAP Platform or the CAP Framework and provide a generic provider server to easily provide static metadata.

The quality and validation aspect turned out to be a big topic of its own ‚Äì we invested in creating a metadata validator that can not only validate ORD, but also the most important metadata formats we transport along inside of it. Quality is also a gradual and moving goal, so we created a concept of ‚Äúpolicy levels‚Äù in which we distinguish between various degrees or goals of quality ‚Äì and can validate which level the published content has achieved.

To increase the quality of the metadata, we realized that we need to come to the validation step early in the process (‚Äúshift left‚Äù), so we don‚Äôt identify issues too late, in the worst case not before publishing. Validation ideally happens in the CI/CD of the local application development. The central publishing targets then act as quality gates to ensure at least a baseline for quality. Therefore, we made sure that our validation runs in the central quality gates and at the same time made it easy for product teams to run the same validations locally.

By continuously validating already published metadata according to old and new rules, we have a data-driven approach to identify where we need to increase quality and which validation rules are realistic to enforce. With this loop, we were already able to improve the metadata and documentation quality of SAP software and can grow it continuously.

Integrating Data Products into ORD

In 2022-2023, when we started the work on SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), the Data Mesh and Data Product topic become very relevant to us as a company. We quickly realized the potential of reusing the ORD specification and the infrastructure for metadata discovery, validation, and cataloging. Even better, by integrating data products into ORD, we were able to ensure that data products are not a silo for data scientists but are interconnected with the existing, more developer-oriented concepts of APIs and Event

We enabled the description of Data Products in ORD to make them describable and discoverable just like other resources. For Data Products, some specialized API protocols like Delta Sharing became relevant to add. At this stage, we also had to extend ORD to describe integration dependencies to indicate input ports (potential data lineage) and we further invested into connecting all ORD concepts with business and domain concepts, like Business Objects (Entity Types). For more background, have a look at the blog post: The Metadata behind SAP Data Products in SAP Business Data Cloud.

We have now started to connect APIs, Events, and Data Products to business processes, as this connects the concepts of various personas (developers, data scientists, business experts). By interlinking the concepts, we help discovery, search and make it easier to understand what belongs together.

Extend with AI and Knowledge Graph

We are currently seeing a rise in specialized AI agent protocols like MCP and A2A. With this comes a need to build registries / catalogs so consumers or agents can discover them. From the ORD perspective, agent or tools are just a special  type of API protocol we could put in the same API catalog - just like Delta Sharing was a new API Protocol geared towards Data Products.

Current efforts on MCP and A2A seem to solve the discovery problem for a single protocol in isolation. However, we see value in having a combined catalog that can include both MCP and A2A ‚Äì and it is likely there will be more agent protocols to follow.

AI agents will benefit from knowledge graphs for further grounding, for helping to avoid AI hallucinations, for storing knowledge explicitly, to reduce the cost and compute of agentic planning, and to provide explain-ability of reasoning. Building an MCP API / proxy around every existing API is costly, so we see potential in bringing in the huge, existing ecosystem of APIs, Events, and Data Products into knowledge graphs. We also see value in having AI to assist with understanding often very complex, customized system landscapes and what they offer, how they can be integrated, and extended.

Establishing ORD as a Linux Foundation Standard

In 2023, ORD was released as an SAP open-source standard, accessible for industry-wide adoption. In 2025 we changed ORD's ownership model, contributing it to the Linux Foundation via the publicly funded ApeiroRA / IPCEI-CIS program. With this we ensure vendor-neutral governance and long-term independence from SAP. The standard is now open to contributions and ownership of other companies as well. Thus, ORD has laid the foundation to potentially become an accepted industry standard. ORD received the 2025 API award in the category ‚ÄúBest in API standards and specification‚Äù.

Our Vision

We believe that we have created something special with ORD: We are not aware of any stable, open-source standard that can handle the metadata discovery of applications / services across different protocols and types of resources, tailored to the requirements of various personas and products. There are a few projects with similar goals ‚Äì some redundant, some complementary ‚Äì as ORD. A detailed comparison would require at least one more blog post, which may come at a different time.

Many years of SAP experience across multiple products, use cases, and stakeholders went into the standard. With ORD, it‚Äôs possible to break up metadata silos and create a well-connected metadata graph of the technical resources in your IT landscape.

We believe that a good metadata integration architecture is an important pillar to achieve transparency in a well-integrated IT landscape and benefits developers, applications and AI alike.

If you have questions, feedback, or interest in collaboration, feel free to create a GitHub issue or reach out to Simon Heimler directly. We are looking forward to collaborating with other companies on the future of ORD. Collaboration with the Technical Steering Committee is very welcome.

entry.title: Re: How to transfer the Planned order from SAP PUBLIC CLO...
entry.content:
As of now, planned order integration from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to SAP DMC is not fully supported out-of-the-box. This limitation is confirmed in SAP‚Äôs Digital Manufacturing Integration Guide here 

So what you can do is build a custom iFlow in SAP Cloud Integration to extract planned orders from S/4HANA Cloud via API. Transform and send them to SAP DMC using supported endpoints. SAP provides integration packages like SAP S/4HANA Integration with SAP Digital Manufacturing. These contain predefined iFlows that can be adapted for REM scenarios

Ensure the following are correctly configured. Communication Arrangement for the relevant API (e.g., Planned Order Integration), Communication User with appropriate roles and Manage Business Settings in DMC where plant must be mapped and integration mode set

entry.title: How to create dynamic value help cds views for domain value?
entry.content:
I create my domain value help like this. 

define view entity x
    as select from dd07t
{
    @ObjectModel.text.element: ['ddtext']
    key domvalue_l as domvalue,
    ddtext
}
where 
    domname = 'x'
    and as4local = 'A'
    and ddlanguage = $session.system_language

"Then use this value help like this 
@Consumption: { valueHelpDefinition: [{ entity: {name: 'X', element: 'domvalue'}}]}

The 'Problem' with this solution is i have to create a new cds view for each domain. I am looking for a more generic approach.

Is there a way to define one value help cds view and use this for all domains? Like the following idea. (Syntax is false, just want to show what i mean)

define view entity GENERIC_DOMAIN_VH
    as select from dd07t
{
    @ObjectModel.text.element: ['ddtext'] 
    key domvalue_l as domvalue,
    ddtext
}
where 
    domname = @parameter
    and as4local = 'A'
    and ddlanguage = $session.system_language

@Consumption: { valueHelpDefinition: [{ entity: {name: 'GENERIC_VALUE_HELP', element: <domainname>}}], filter: { multipleSelections: false} }

I tried it with association inside my cds view and parameter in the value help but without success.
